  14. (**************************************************************************)

  16. (** The interface of a -ppx rewriter

  18.   A -ppx rewriter is a program that accepts a serialized abstract syntax
  19.   tree and outputs another, possibly modified, abstract syntax tree.
  20.   This module encapsulates the interface between the compiler and
  21.   the -ppx rewriters, handling such details as the serialization format,
  22.   forwarding of command-line flags, and storing state.

  24.   {!mapper} enables AST rewriting using open recursion.
  25.   A typical mapper would be based on {!default_mapper}, a deep
  26.   identity mapper, and will fall back on it for handling the syntax it
  27.   does not modify. For example:

  29.   {[
  30. open Asttypes
  31. open Parsetree
  32. open Ast_mapper

  34. let test_mapper argv =
  35.   { default_mapper with
  36.     expr = fun mapper expr ->
  37.       match expr with
  38.       | { pexp_desc = Pexp_extension ({ txt = "test" }, PStr [])} ->
  39.         Ast_helper.Exp.constant (Const_int 42)
  40.       | other -> default_mapper.expr mapper other; }

  42. let () =
  43.   register "ppx_test" test_mapper]}

  45.   This -ppx rewriter, which replaces [[%test]] in expressions with
  46.   the constant [42], can be compiled using
  47.   [ocamlc -o ppx_test -I +compiler-libs ocamlcommon.cma ppx_test.ml].

  49.   {b Warning:} this module is unstable and part of
  50.   {{!Compiler_libs}compiler-libs}.

  52.   *)

  54. open Parsetree

  56. (** {1 A generic Parsetree mapper} *)

  58. ‌type mapper = {
  59.   attribute: mapper -> attribute -> attribute;
  60.   attributes: mapper -> attribute list -> attribute list;
  61.   binding_op: mapper -> binding_op -> binding_op;
  62.   case: mapper -> case -> case;
  63.   cases: mapper -> case list -> case list;
  64.   class_declaration: mapper -> class_declaration -> class_declaration;
  65.   class_description: mapper -> class_description -> class_description;
  66.   class_expr: mapper -> class_expr -> class_expr;
  67.   class_field: mapper -> class_field -> class_field;
  68.   class_signature: mapper -> class_signature -> class_signature;
  69.   class_structure: mapper -> class_structure -> class_structure;
  70.   class_type: mapper -> class_type -> class_type;
  71.   class_type_declaration: mapper -> class_type_declaration
  72.                           -> class_type_declaration;
  73.   class_type_field: mapper -> class_type_field -> class_type_field;
  74.   constant: mapper -> constant -> constant;
  75.   constructor_declaration: mapper -> constructor_declaration
  76.                            -> constructor_declaration;
  77.   expr: mapper -> expression -> expression;
  78.   extension: mapper -> extension -> extension;
  79.   extension_constructor: mapper -> extension_constructor
  80.                          -> extension_constructor;
  81.   include_declaration: mapper -> include_declaration -> include_declaration;
  82.   include_description: mapper -> include_description -> include_description;
  83.   label_declaration: mapper -> label_declaration -> label_declaration;
  84.   location: mapper -> Location.t -> Location.t;
  85.   module_binding: mapper -> module_binding -> module_binding;
  86.   module_declaration: mapper -> module_declaration -> module_declaration;
  87.   module_substitution: mapper -> module_substitution -> module_substitution;
  88.   module_expr: mapper -> module_expr -> module_expr;
  89.   module_type: mapper -> module_type -> module_type;
  90.   module_type_declaration: mapper -> module_type_declaration
  91.                            -> module_type_declaration;
  92.   open_declaration: mapper -> open_declaration -> open_declaration;
  93.   open_description: mapper -> open_description -> open_description;
  94.   pat: mapper -> pattern -> pattern;
  95.   payload: mapper -> payload -> payload;
  96.   signature: mapper -> signature -> signature;
  97.   signature_item: mapper -> signature_item -> signature_item;
  98.   structure: mapper -> structure -> structure;
  99.   structure_item: mapper -> structure_item -> structure_item;
  100.   typ: mapper -> core_type -> core_type;
  101.   type_declaration: mapper -> type_declaration -> type_declaration;
  102.   type_extension: mapper -> type_extension -> type_extension;
  103.   type_exception: mapper -> type_exception -> type_exception;
  104.   type_kind: mapper -> type_kind -> type_kind;
  105.   value_binding: mapper -> value_binding -> value_binding;
  106.   value_description: mapper -> value_description -> value_description;
  107.   with_constraint: mapper -> with_constraint -> with_constraint;
  108. }
  109. (** A mapper record implements one "method" per syntactic category,
  110.     using an open recursion style: each method takes as its first
  111.     argument the mapper to be applied to children in the syntax
  112.     tree. *)

  114. ‌val default_mapper: mapper
  115. (** A default mapper, which implements a "deep identity" mapping. *)

  117. (** {1 Apply mappers to compilation units} *)

  119. ‌val tool_name: unit -> string
  120. (** Can be used within a ppx preprocessor to know which tool is
  121.     calling it ["ocamlc"], ["ocamlopt"], ["ocamldoc"], ["ocamldep"],
  122.     ["ocaml"], ...  Some global variables that reflect command-line
  123.     options are automatically synchronized between the calling tool
  124.     and the ppx preprocessor: {!Clflags.include_dirs},
  125.     {!Load_path}, {!Clflags.open_modules}, {!Clflags.for_package},
  126.     {!Clflags.debug}. *)


  129. ‌val apply: source:string -> target:string -> mapper -> unit
  130. (** Apply a mapper (parametrized by the unit name) to a dumped
  131.     parsetree found in the [source] file and put the result in the
  132.     [target] file. The [structure] or [signature] field of the mapper
  133.     is applied to the implementation or interface.  *)

  135. ‌val run_main: (string list -> mapper) -> unit
  136. (** Entry point to call to implement a standalone -ppx rewriter from a
  137.     mapper, parametrized by the command line arguments.  The current
  138.     unit name can be obtained from {!Location.input_name}.  This
  139.     function implements proper error reporting for uncaught
  140.     exceptions. *)

  142. (** {1 Registration API} *)

  144. ‌val register_function: (string -> (string list -> mapper) -> unit) ref

  146. ‌val register: string -> (string list -> mapper) -> unit
  147. (** Apply the [register_function].  The default behavior is to run the
  148.     mapper immediately, taking arguments from the process command
  149.     line.  This is to support a scenario where a mapper is linked as a
  150.     stand-alone executable.

  152.     It is possible to overwrite the [register_function] to define
  153.     "-ppx drivers", which combine several mappers in a single process.
  154.     Typically, a driver starts by defining [register_function] to a
  155.     custom implementation, then lets ppx rewriters (linked statically
  156.     or dynamically) register themselves, and then run all or some of
  157.     them.  It is also possible to have -ppx drivers apply rewriters to
  158.     only specific parts of an AST.

  160.     The first argument to [register] is a symbolic name to be used by
  161.     the ppx driver.  *)


  164. (** {1 Convenience functions to write mappers} *)

  166. ‌val map_opt: ('a -> 'b) -> 'a option -> 'b option

  168. ‌val extension_of_error: Location.error -> extension
  169. (** Encode an error into an 'ocaml.error' extension node which can be
  170.     inserted in a generated Parsetree.  The compiler will be
  171.     responsible for reporting the error. *)

  173. ‌val attribute_of_warning: Location.t -> string -> attribute
  174. (** Encode a warning message into an 'ocaml.ppwarning' attribute which can be
  175.     inserted in a generated Parsetree.  The compiler will be
  176.     responsible for reporting the warning. *)

  178. (** {1 Helper functions to call external mappers} *)

  180. ‌val add_ppx_context_str:
  181.     tool_name:string -> Parsetree.structure -> Parsetree.structure
  182. (** Extract information from the current environment and encode it
  183.     into an attribute which is prepended to the list of structure
  184.     items in order to pass the information to an external
  185.     processor. *)

  187. ‌val add_ppx_context_sig:
  188.     tool_name:string -> Parsetree.signature -> Parsetree.signature
  189. (** Same as [add_ppx_context_str], but for signatures. *)

  191. ‌val drop_ppx_context_str:
  192.     restore:bool -> Parsetree.structure -> Parsetree.structure
  193. (** Drop the ocaml.ppx.context attribute from a structure.  If
  194.     [restore] is true, also restore the associated data in the current
  195.     process. *)

  197. ‌val drop_ppx_context_sig:
  198.     restore:bool -> Parsetree.signature -> Parsetree.signature
  199. (** Same as [drop_ppx_context_str], but for signatures. *)

  201. (** {1 Cookies} *)

  203. (** Cookies are used to pass information from a ppx processor to
  204.     a further invocation of itself, when called from the OCaml
  205.     toplevel (or other tools that support cookies). *)

  207. ‌val set_cookie: string -> Parsetree.expression -> unit
  208. ‌val get_cookie: string -> Parsetree.expression option
